posts.name:
Dr. Radhika Dirks
Dr. Radhika Dirks
posts.content:
Sam Altman thinks it's "perfectly fine" for our children to grow up in a world where AI outsmarts them - this is deeply unsettling. 

While I too don’t expect HIS kid to be smarter than AI  what troubles me here isn't the surface-level statement. It's the dangerous subtext beneath:

The implicit suggestion that humans don't need to be smarter than AI.

As someone who's spent over a decade building AI technology, I can tell you this is precisely the kind of thinking that could lead to the biggest crisis in human cognitive development.

Think about this: Every major human advancement, from discovering fire to developing vaccines, came from our ability to think deeply and solve complex problems.

This cognitive muscle is what makes us uniquely human. Yet, we're rapidly entering an era where this muscle is atrophying.

When Altman suggests that "figuring out what questions to ask will be more important than figuring out the answer," he's highlighting a troubling shift.

We're moving from being problem solvers to prompt engineers.

We're surrendering the very capabilities that define us as humans.

Now, we're not just building tools to augment human intelligence anymore – we're creating systems that replace our core thinking processes, and worse, we're beginning to accept this as inevitable.

When calculators became the norm, mental math capabilities took a hit.

Now, the same is happening with writing — through LLMs like ChatGPT.

Sure, AI-human collaboration is powerful.

But each time we outsource thinking to AI, we're not just getting an answer – we're missing an opportunity to strengthen our mental capabilities.

As a parent and tech professional, I see both sides. Yes, AI will create new opportunities.

But should we really be comfortable with our children growing up in a world where being "less smart than AI" is the accepted norm?

My answer's obvious - what's yours?

comments.commentText: Like it or not he is right. You can’t stop it, you can’t choose, it will happen in a couple of days. And we need to adapt. And we always adapt. Exciting future ahead :)
I am sympathetic to these ideas. However, will intelligence in any of its current forms (copied by AIs) really be the deciding factor of the futures?

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Emphasizing critical thinking and problem-solving skills is crucial as we navigate this AI-driven future. Lets nurture our cognitive abilities!

posts.name:
Hlib Storchak
Hlib Storchak
posts.content:
Want a more efficient business?
Start by letting go of battles that drain your focus.

Some objections aren't worth fighting.

Let me tell you why.

 Not every client is a fit.
Understanding this saves time and energy.

 Focus on the willing.
Spend your resources on those who see your value.

 Maintain your integrity.
Don't compromise just to win an argument.

 Streamline your process.
Identify objections that are deal-breakers early on.

 Build stronger relationships.
Focus on clients who align with your vision.

In business, efficiency matters most.

That's because:

→ Without clarity, you lose direction.
→ Without integrity, you lose respect.
→ Without the right clients, you can't grow.
→ Without focus, you spread yourself too thin.
→ Without alignment, you face constant friction.

Great leaders know when to move on.

They recognize the value of their time.

They build a culture of mutual respect and understanding.

So, if you want to lead effectively,
Choose your battles wisely.

Because when you do, everyone wins.

And that, my friends, is the mark of a smart leader.

What objections have you decided aren’t worth fighting?

comments.commentText: Spot on! Picking your battles saves time and energy for what truly matters. What's your 'not worth it' line in business?

posts.commentAdded: “Absolutely agree! Focusing on the right clients and maintaining integrity are key to driving efficiency and growth. Great insights!

posts.name:
Roman M.
Roman M.
posts.content:
This time will not be different!

Below a 12-month chart (every candle = 12 months) of the S&P 500 from 1893 till today. Sorry it's not a log chart.

The indicator below shows a recurring super-cycle. On every downturn of the indictor the market goes sideways/downward for 10-15 years on average; sometimes longer (i.e. 1929 - 1953). The second chart shows the earlier years better.

I realize that four cycles isn't statistically significant, but it looks as if we could expect another 10 - 15-year sideways/down sometime soon.
posts.commentAdded: Interesting analysis! It’s crucial to stay vigilant in these cycles. History has much to teach us about market behavior.

posts.name:
Jason Bramble
Jason Bramble
posts.content:
Your urgency will always dictate how much you’re willing to tolerate:

- Your urgency for success
- Your urgency for happiness
- Your urgency to become the best version of yourself
- Your urgency to build the best marriage possible
- Your urgency to chase your dreams

The list goes on.

If there’s one thing I’ve learned over five years as an entrepreneur, it’s this: It’s not easy, especially for someone with a good heart and an empathetic nature, to avoid giving people or situations the benefit of the doubt.

If that sounds like you, my advice is simple: Without boundaries, clear expectations for yourself and others, and a conscious evaluation of who you allow into your life, you risk losing the urgency to pursue what truly matters.

Decide what *your thing* is, and go after it. Protect your energy and approach life with the urgency to surround yourself only with the people, places, and things that align with your purpose.


•

•


•

•
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Prioritizing boundaries and clarity is essential for staying aligned with our goals. Lets protect that urgency! 💪✨

posts.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
posts.content:
If you’re not great at forecasting, you’re basically flying a plane with no radar. Sure, you might land safely, but do you really want to take that chance?

Here’s the harsh truth: Every revenue operation team talks about improving conversion rates, increasing sales, and hitting quotas—but nobody wants to talk about forecasting. Why? Because it’s hard—and it doesn’t have the instant gratification of a closed deal.

At, we’ve seen it time and time again: Companies throw money at marketing, boost their sales teams, but ignore the one thing that makes it all run smoothly: Predicting what’s actually going to happen. Because, spoiler alert, it’s not magic, it’s data.

Forecasting is your secret weapon. Here’s why:

1️⃣ It’s the Crystal Ball You’re Avoiding: We all wish we could predict the future, right? Well, forecasting is the closest you’ll get. It’s not perfect, but it lets you anticipate revenue, identify gaps, and plan your growth.Without it, you're just guessing.

2️⃣ It’s the Only Way to Avoid a Panic Attack Ever been blindsided by a quarter where sales didn’t hit expectations, and suddenly, everyone’s in damage control mode? A solid forecast lets you spot trends early so you’re not scrambling at the last minute. It's better to worry early, trust me.

3️⃣ It’s a Skill, Not a Guess If you think forecasting is just about crossing your fingers and praying, you’re doing it wrong. It’s about analyzing data, spotting patterns, and using all the smart tools you can to make educated guesses. The best forecasts are built on real insights, not on wishful thinking.

4️⃣ It Gets Easier With AI (Yes, I Had to Say It) If you're still relying on gut feel or spreadsheets to forecast, you're doing it the hard way. Here at, we use AI to help companies fine-tune their sales forecasts in real-time. Trust me—there's a reason AI’s the future. It's a game-changer.

So, take a step back and ask yourself: Are you forecasting like a boss, or are you just crossing your fingers and hoping for the best?

Get ahead of the curve. Forecast better, grow smarter.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Forecasting is the backbone of strategic growth—it transforms hope into actionable insights. Time to embrace the power of data! 📈

posts.name:
Hartmut Hübner, PhD
Hartmut Hübner, PhD
posts.content:
60% of people feel betrayed by institutions.

The 2025 Edelman Trust Barometer shows trust in the system is broken.

 Distrust in governments, media, and NGOs is at an all-time high.
 6 in 10 people believe the system benefits the wealthy while they struggle with rising costs and misinformation.
 Business is now the most trusted institution—seen as competent and ethical—but trust is fragile.

Richard Edelman says:

“Trust must be restored for hope to return. Business can lead by creating jobs, reskilling workers, and delivering sustainable solutions—but it can’t act alone.”

Why trust has shifted to businesses:

1️⃣ Business is seen as competent and more ethical than other institutions.
2️⃣ Companies that invest in impactful products and local jobs earn trust.
3️⃣ Business leaders are expected to address systemic issues and contribute to solutions.

The key lever for trust is communication.

7 steps to build trust as a leader through communication that builds on dialogue and triggers action:

1️⃣ Be transparent.
↳ Share wins and lessons learned in real time.
↳ Make your position clear in the public discussion.

2️⃣ Invest in building future skills.
↳ Train employees in communication and critical thinking.
↳ Provide employees access to AI tools and train employees how to use it safely for real productivity gains.

3️⃣ Engage local communities.
↳ Solve local problems like childcare.
↳ Invest in local infrastructure and mobility solutions.

4️⃣ Create a growth culture.
↳ Champion inclusion.
↳ Put your company values in action and track them.

5️⃣ Use data wisely.
↳ Make decisions based on evidence.
↳ Share customer feedback to drive change.

6️⃣ Speak clearly.
↳ Replace jargon with plain language.
↳ Apply this across all channels and in meetings.

7️⃣ Show empathy.
↳ Apply generative listening.
↳ Use the knowledge and power of the crowd.

 Trust is fragile but there are ways to rebuild it.

Start in small steps. Focus on action and transparency.

 Followfor more insights on culture, communication and productivity.
 Subscribe to The Flow Factor for weekly tools to work smarter (link in profile).

comments.commentText: Trust truly hinges on transparency, action, and community engagement. Businesses can lead by not only addressing systemic issues but by empowering employees and local communities.

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Transparency and community engagement are key to regaining trust. Lets prioritize actions that matter! #TrustInBusiness
